study_plan_entry.title: Dynamic nuclear polarization and hyperpolarization techniques

free_text.Learning outcomes: The course is intended for students who are working or wish to work in NMR, ESR or MRI. [br/]The main objectives are the following:[br/]b) To introduce and define the sensitivity issues in magnetic resonance and the potential ways to tackle them.[br/]a) To give graduate students the conceptual tools to understand the principles of dynamic nuclear polarization and hyperpolarization techniques.[br/]c) To give an overview of the applications of dynamic nuclear polarization and hyperpolarization techniques in NMR and MRI.[br/]
free_text.Content: 1. Review of important concepts in quantum mechanics (spin, density matrix,...)[br/]2. Review of important concepts in thermodynamics (temperature, entropy,...)[br/]3. Magnetic resonance: basic concepts in NMR and ESR[br/]4. Spin interactions: dipolar, J- and hyperfine couplings[br/]5. Spin relaxation: electron spin and nuclear spin relaxation mechanisms[br/]6. Spin temperature: a thermodynamical description of spin systems[br/]7. Sensitivity issues in magnetic resonance[br/]8. Polarization transfer methods[br/]9. Overhauser effect: DNP in liquid state[br/]10. Solid effect and spin diffusion[br/]11. Thermal mixing: thermodynamic model of DNP[br/]12. Solid-state DNP techniques: concepts and hardware[br/]13. Hyperpolarization methods: brute force, optical pumping, PHIP, dissolution DNP[br/]14. Biomedical applications[br/]
free_text.Keywords: Dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP), Hyperpolarization, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR)
